results.title: Greenhouse effect: we can all make a difference
results.brief_description: An animated collage of fast-moving images which focuses on the problems of the Green-house effect and what solutions can be tried. Would provide an interesting starting point for discussion with upper primary/lower secondary students.

results.title: Greenhouse Effect
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
The “Greenhouse Effect” is explained and the consequent predictions about climate change are detailed with reference to possible impact. Hosted by weatherman, Rob Gell.

results.title: Greenhouse
results.creator_credit: William C. Crain and Barr Films
results.brief_description: A young boy’s work to repair a greenhouse he has vandalised helps him top appreciate the beauty of nature and to learn the meaning of friendship and a respect for the property of others.

results.title: Green tea and cherry ripe
results.brief_description: Green Tea and Cherry Ripe tells the story of six Japanese women who married Australian servicemen after the Second World War, their efforts to build new lives in Australia and the challenges they faced in an alien land.

results.title: Green garden country
results.creator_credit: Conon Fraser, Geoffrey Scott, Ronald Bowie and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: From parks and public gardens to the backyard enthusiast, this film shows how New Zealand’s extraordinary variety of shrubs and flowers from all parts of the world contribute to an enviable way of life in New Zealand.

results.title: Green engineering: simple solutions to water pollution
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cozens, Environment Protection Authority and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Using the Yarra River as an example, this video shows how sediment pollution of rivers can be reduced by using green engineering and how silt traps at building sites can be useful on eroded sites.

results.title: Green ceilings of Borneo
results.brief_description: In the dense tree-tops of the Borneo jungle, animals have adapted to the problem of getting from one tree-top to another without climbing down. This shows gliding lizards, squirrels, snakes, orang-utan and a large fruit bat.
